Mr. P. Conrey, Jun., presented the following reJ
olutions, with some happy remarks, in which he al
luded to the doubts which had been thrown out cofl
cerning the want of sympathy on the part of tl
city, to the object of the Convention. In order to
do awajr with any such feeling, a meeting had been
held by the Orleans, Algiers, Gretna, and Jeft'orso!
Delegations, and he was happy to report the follow-in]
resolutions, which had been unanimously adopted :
Resolved, That the delegations from Orleans, Algiers anl
Gretna, have heard with great gratification, the manifest*
tions of zeal evinced by the delegates from the other parishJ
represented in this convention.
Resolved, That the delegations from the above named.pa
rishes will meet the delegates from the distant parishes,
heart and hand, and will cordially co-operate with tbem in
promoting the objecfs of this convention.
Resolved, That the delegates from Orleans, Algiers ana
Gretna, doubt not that the parishes of Orleans and Jefferson'
will fully and faithfully sustain us (their representatives) ill
pledging them, as we now do, to a generous and equitable
contribution towards the construction of the Opelousas, At
takapas and New Orleans Railroad.
The resolutions were received with much approbation.
Mr. Hanna, of Terrebonne, presented the follows
ing preamble and resolution:
Whereas, The probable route of the railroad through tha
parish of Terrebonne will leave Houma about seven miles
south,
Resolved, That the Permanent Committee be instructed to
provide a branch road to said town, as it will develope a
